fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ayberk Tosun
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: https://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~axt978/
University of Birmingham

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: PhD Student at the University of Birmingham.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zoo of notions of (im)predicativity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: notes from a talk by Escardó, with some additions by Ayberk Tosun

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Russell's ramified type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all sets of a given type gives a set of the next type.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of Russell’s Reducibility Axiom
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: pp. 241 of Mathematical Logic based on the Theory of Types

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Axiom of Reducibility states that any truth function (i.e. propositional function) can be expressed by a formally equivalent predicative truth function.
This is where the term “predicative” originates from as it says propositional functions can be reduced to predicates.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of System F
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all types in the first universe gives a type in the first universe.
This form of impredicativity is also present in the Calculus of Constructions and the Calculus of Inductive Constructions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of topos logic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Aczel's CZF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is not allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of MLTT

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over the types in one universe gives a type in the next universe.
This is similar to axt-005Z.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is the same as axt-0062 since HoTT/UF is a system extending a particular MLTT with univalence and so-called higher-inductive types.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Voevodsky’s propositional resizing axiom is assumed. There are several forms of this axiom of varying strengths but they are all variations of the statement that propositional types quantifying over other types are small.
This seems to be somewhat similar to axt-0067.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Feferman

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any theory that has the strength of the Feferman-Schütte ordinal or above is deemed to be impredicative.

Let X be a large and locally small locale. An open U : \mathcal {O}( X ) is called supercompact if for any small inhabited family (I, V_{(-)}), U \le \bigvee _{i : I} V_i \rightarrow \exists k : I. \ U \le V_k.

A large and locally small locale X is called superspectral if it satisfies the following conditions:
X is a supercompact locale.
The meet of two supercompact opens is supercompact.
The type of supercompact opens of X is small.
For every open U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a small directed family (I_U, \kappa _{U}) on U satisfying:
U = \bigvee _{k : K} \kappa _{U}(k).
The open \kappa (i) is supercompact for every i : I.
Given a preordered set (A, \le ), there are a couple of natural topologies on it to consider.
The Alexandroff topology is the finest topology whose specialization preorder coincides with the order \le.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Alexandroff topology
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Prop. 4.2.11 of Goubault-Larrecq

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a preordered set. The Alexandroff topology on A is given by the class of upward closed subsets of A (which always form a topology).
Let A be a set equipped with a preorder \le. The specialization preorder of the Alexandroff topology on A coincides with the order \le.

The specialization preorder in the context of the Alexandroff topology amounts to: x \le _{ \uparrow } y \vcentcolon \equiv \forall U \in \operatorname { \uparrow }( A ) . \ x \in U \rightarrow y \in U .
(\Rightarrow) Let x, y \in A with x \le y and consider an arbitrary U \in \operatorname { \uparrow }( A ) containing x. Because y \ge x it is immediate that y \in U by the upward closure of U.

(\Leftarrow) Let x, y \in A with x \le _{ \uparrow } y. The principal filter \operatorname { \uparrow }( x ) must be an open in the Alexandroff topology as it is upward closed. Since x \in \operatorname { \uparrow }( x ), we immediately have y \in \operatorname { \uparrow }( x ) by the definition of \le _{ \uparrow }. which is to say x \le y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Prop. 4.2.11 of Goubault-Larrecq

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set equipped with a preorder \le. The Alexandroff topology on A is finer than any topology whose specialization preorder coincides with ( \le ).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let \mathcal {T} be a topology on A such that the specialization preorder \le _{ \mathcal {T}} coincides with the order \le. Let U \subseteq A be a \mathcal {T}-open. The open subset U must be upward closed with respect to \le _{ \mathcal {T}} by axt-002Z. Since \le _ \mathcal {T} coincides with \le, this means that U is upward closed with respect to the order \le on A, which is to say it is an Alexandroff open.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a preordered set (A, \le ), the Alexandroff topology is the finest one among the topologies whose specialization preorders coincide with the order \le.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We know by axt-005Q that the specialization preorder of the Alexandroff topology always coincides with the order \le. Furthermore, we know by axt-005R that it is finer than any topology whose specialization preorder coincides with the order \le.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The upper topology is, in a sense, the dual of the Alexandroff topology: it is the coarsest possible topology whose specialization preorder coincides with the order \le.
Let X be a preordered set. The upper topology of X is the one generated by the subbasis consisting of complements of principal ideals.
Let X be a preordered set. The lower topology on X is the topology generated by the subbasis consisting of complements of principal filters.
In impredicative locale theory, the notion of a maxset is defined as:

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Maxset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paragraph 13.2 (p. 66) of Wilson's thesis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let L be a frame. A subset M \subseteq L is called a maxset if,
it is closed under arbitrary meets, and
it is an exponential ideal i.e. \forall x \in L. \ \forall m \in M. \ (x \Rightarrow m) \in M.
It is a standard fact of locale theory that there is a correspondence between the set of nuclei on, and the class of maxsets of, every frame.
Let L be a frame and j : L \to L a nucleus on it. The set of fixed points of j forms a maxset.
Let L be a small-complete and large and locally small lattice with a small intensional basis. If L is small-cocomplete then it is also small-complete.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Denote by (B, \beta ) the small basis of L. Let (I, \iota ) be a \mathcal {U}-small family. We need to show that it has a greatest lower bound. Consider the family of lowerbounds for (I, \iota ): \mathfrak {L}_ \iota \vcentcolon \equiv \left ( \left ( \sum _{ b \ : \ B } \prod _{ i : I } \beta (b) \le \iota (i) \right ), \beta \circ \mathsf {pr}_1 \right ), which is a small family. We claim that the join \bigvee \mathfrak {L}_ \iota is the greatest lower bound of (I, \iota ).
First, notice that it is obviously a lower bound because for any i : I, \left ( \bigvee \mathfrak {L}_ \iota \right ) \le \iota (i) since \iota (i) is an upper bound of \mathfrak {L}_ \iota by construction.
Let l be a lower bound of (I, \iota ). By the assumption that (B, \beta ) is a basis for L, we know that there exists a family (J_l, \gamma _l) such that l = \bigvee _{j : J_l} \beta ( \gamma _l(j)). Therefore, it suffices to show \bigvee _{j : J_l} \beta ( \gamma _l(j)) \le \bigvee \mathfrak {L}_ \iota . For any j : J_l, the element \beta ( \gamma _l(j)) clearly falls in \mathfrak {L}_j itself since \beta ( \gamma _l(j)) \le l

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointed dcpo fixed point theorem III

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (D, \sqsubseteq ) be a pointed dcpo and F : D \to D an inflationary endomap on it. There exists a least fixed point for function F.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Knaster-Tarski fixed point theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn 2.35 of Davey and Priestley

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L be a complete lattice and F : L \to L a monotone map. Then the set \alpha \vcentcolon \equiv \bigvee \left \{ x \in L \mid x \le F(x) \right \} is a fixed point of F.
We first define the abbreviation H \vcentcolon \equiv \{ x \in L \mid x \le F( x ) \}.

To show F( \alpha ) = \alpha, we use antisymmetry. For the ( \ge ) direction, it suffices to show F( \alpha ) is an upper bound of H. Let x \in H. We know x \le \alpha as \alpha is the least upper bound of H which implies F(x) \le F( \alpha ). We also know x \le F(x) by the definition of H which means x \le F(x) \le F( \alpha ). For the ( \le ) direction, notice that we know F( \alpha ) \le F(F( \alpha )) by the fact we just showed which means F( \alpha ) \in H. It follows that F( \alpha ) \le \alpha since \alpha is the least upper bound of H.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An extensional spectral basis (B, \beta ) for a \mathcal {W}-locale is an intensional spectral basis that is extensional.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
An intensional spectral basis for a \mathcal {W}-locale X is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) for the frame \mathcal {O}( X ) (considered as a \mathcal {W}-dcpo) that satisfies the following two conditions
For every b : B, \beta (b) is a compact open of X.
The basis (B, \beta ) is closed under finite meets. This is to say that it satisfies the following conditions.
It contains the empty meet: \exists t : B. \ \mathsf {isTop}( \beta (t)).
It is closed under binary meets: \forall b_1, b_2 : B. \ \exists b_3 : B \ \beta (b_3) \ \text {is the glb of} \ \{ \beta (b_2), \beta (b_3) \} .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact open of a locale in UF
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 3.5 of Tosun and Escardó

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale. An open U : \mathcal {O}( X ) is called compact if the principal filter on U is inaccessible by joins of directed \mathcal {W}-families.

The initial frame at universe \mathcal {U} in UF is the type \Omega _{ \mathcal {U} } viewed as a ( \mathcal {U} ^+, \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {U} )-frame as follows:
Order: P \le Q \vcentcolon \equiv P \Rightarrow Q.
Top element: \mathbf {1} \vcentcolon \equiv \top _{ \mathcal {U} } .
Meet: P \wedge Q \vcentcolon \equiv P \times Q.
Arbitrary join: \left ( \bigvee _{i : I} P_i \right ) \vcentcolon \equiv \exists k : I. \ P_k .

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called spectral if it satisfies the following three conditions.
It is a compact locale (i.e. the empty meet is compact).
The meet of two compact opens is compact.
For every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of compact opens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isCompact}( \kappa _{U}(k) ).

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called spectral if it satisfies the following three conditions.
It is a compact locale (i.e. the empty meet is compact).
The meet of two compact opens is compact.
For every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of compact opens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isCompact}( \kappa _{U}(k) ).

Notice the relationship of the third condition here to pseudocontinuity. If we formulate a notion of “pseudoalgebraicity” i.e. the analogue of pseudocontinuity for algebraicity, we could use that to avoid the repetition here because they are exactly the same thing. This is not good for presentation purposes (as for as locale theory is concerned), however, so it should probably be recorded as an equivalence.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
An intensional spectral basis for a \mathcal {W}-locale X is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) for the frame \mathcal {O}( X ) (considered as a \mathcal {W}-dcpo) that satisfies the following two conditions
For every b : B, \beta (b) is a compact open of X.
The basis (B, \beta ) is closed under finite meets. This is to say that it satisfies the following conditions.
It contains the empty meet: \exists t : B. \ \mathsf {isTop}( \beta (t)).
It is closed under binary meets: \forall b_1, b_2 : B. \ \exists b_3 : B \ \beta (b_3) \ \text {is the glb of} \ \{ \beta (b_2), \beta (b_3) \} .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extensional spectral basis for a locale

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An extensional spectral basis (B, \beta ) for a \mathcal {W}-locale is an intensional spectral basis that is extensional.

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called zero-dimensional if it satisfies the following condition: for every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of clopens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isClopen}( \kappa _{U}(k)).

A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-locale X is called zero-dimensional if it satisfies the following condition: for every U : \mathcal {O}( X ), there exists a directed \mathcal {W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) that satisfies the following conditions.
(K_U, \kappa _U) is directed.
U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \kappa _U(k).
It consists of clopens i.e. \forall k : K_U. \ \mathsf {isClopen}( \kappa _{U}(k)).
In our presentation here, we decouple the notion of a basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo from any kind of compactness or relative compactness requirements.

In the context of domain theory, the natural notion of basis should include such requirements (see for example Defn. 2.2.3 of Abramsky and Jung). As our presentation here is intended to be applicable to a class of lattices broader than that of dcpos, however, we attempt to keep the presentation free of bias towards a specific attitude. This is our motivation for the aforementioned decoupling.

When the notion of a \mathcal {V}-dcpo attains a specific attitude, such as that of a denotational domain, it is perfectly fine for these terms to be overloaded to refer to concepts that include these requirements.

Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo. An intensional basis for D is a \mathcal {V}-family (B, \beta ) on D satisfying the condition: for every element x : D, there is a specified directed \mathcal {V}-family (I_x, \iota _x) on the basis index B such that x = \bigvee (I_x, \beta \circ \iota _x).
Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo. An intensional basis (B, \beta ) for D is called an extensional basis if \beta is an embedding.

In Tom de Jong's thesis and his Agda formalization of domain theory, the term “structurally continuous” is used to mean a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D equipped with a function giving, for every x : D, a small directed family of elements way below x, giving x as its join.
In the new terminology, this notion of “structure” involved in the continuity of a dcpo is made explicit by the following notion.

A continuity datum for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

Factoring this structure out into a definition of its own obviates the need to have a name for the notion of a “\mathcal {V}-dcpo having a specified continuity datum”, which is what “structurally continuous” means. Even though the equivalence between structurally continuous and “having a specified continuity datum” is completely trivial, we still record this in the following proposition to be able to explicitly refer to this terminological identity.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn 4.4.1 of de Jong's PhD thesis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D having a specified continuity datum is the same thing as D being structurally continuous.

By replacing the specified existence here with mere existence, we obtain the notion of a continuous \mathcal {V}-dcpo. The terminology for this is unchanged (i.e. is the same as the terminology of Tom de Jong's thesis).
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo is called continuous if there exists a continuity datum for it.

A \mathcal {V}-dcpo is called pseudocontinuous if there is a specified function giving, for every x : D, the mere existence of a \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D satisfying the following conditions.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) \ll x.

A \mathcal {V}-dcpo being pseudocontinuous is the same thing as it having a specified continuity datum, but with the specified existence requirement in the notion of continuity datum relaxed to requirement of mere existence.

An intensional continuous basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) with the further requirement that for every x : D, the directed \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) given by the basis satisfies the condition \forall k : K_x. \ \beta ( \kappa _x(k)) \ll x.
An extensional continuous basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional continuous basis that is extensional.

An algebraicity datum for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is a function giving, for every x : D, a specified \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \kappa _x) on D that satisfies the following.
The family (K_x, \kappa _x) is directed.
x = \bigvee ^{ \uparrow }_{k : K_x} \kappa _x(k).
For each k : K_x, \kappa _x(k) is compact.

Similar to the case of a continuity datum, we record the terminological identity between a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D being “structurally algebraic” (the terminology from de Jong's thesis) and it having a specified algebraicity datum.
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D having a specified algebraicity datum is the same thing as D being structurally algebraic.
A \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if there exists an algebraicity datum for it.

Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo and define the type K_x \vcentcolon \equiv \sum _{c : D}{ \mathsf {isCompact}( c ) \times c \sqsubseteq x} of compact elements below a given x : D. The \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if it satisfies the following conditions.
For every x : D, K_x is \mathcal {V}-small.
The \mathcal {V}-family (K_x, \mathsf {pr}_1 ) is directed with supremum x.
An intensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional basis (B, \beta ) satisfying \forall b : B. \ \mathsf {isCompact}( \beta (b) ) .
An extensional algebraic basis for a \mathcal {V}-dcpo D is an intensional algebraic basis (B, \beta ) that is extensional.
Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo. An intensional basis (B, \beta ) for D is called an extensional basis if \beta is an embedding.

Let D be a \mathcal {V}-dcpo. An intensional basis for D is a \mathcal {V}-family (B, \beta ) on D satisfying the condition: for every element x : D, there is a specified directed \mathcal {V}-family (I_x, \iota _x) on the basis index B such that x = \bigvee (I_x, \beta \circ \iota _x).
A locale X is called large and locally small if it is given by a ( \mathcal {U} ^+, \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {U} )-frame.
The following is the summary of my understanding of Longley and Normann's discussion in Section 3.2.1 of their book on higher-order computability.
Consider a function F : \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } \to \mathbb {N}, that is computable in an intuitive sense.

Given some g \in \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} }, when the function F returns a result F(g) \in \mathbb {N}, it must do so after a finite examination of the input g. This is to say that there must be some r \in \mathbb {N} such that F "looks at" only the values g(0), \ldots , g(i_{r-1}). So the result F(g) is determined solely using the information of the behaviour of g on the inputs 0, \ldots , i_{r-1}.

Attempting to capture this idea of F being determined solely on a finite amount of information about the behaviour of g, we are naturally led to the notion of continuity: F cannot distinguish between g and any other function g' \in \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } that returns the same values as those of g on inputs 0, \ldots , i_{r-1}. In other words, \forall g' \in \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } . \ \forall k \in \{ 0, \ldots , r-1 \} . \ g(i_k) = g'(i_k) \rightarrow F(g) = F(g').

This is precisely the same thing as saying that F is continuous with respect to the standard Baire topology on \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } and the discrete topology \mathbb {N}. Continuity is merely a necessary condition for computability as there are many continuous functions F : \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } \to \mathbb {N} that are not computable (in any sense). The idea, however, is that an abstract model of computation based only on this necessary condition will already capture some interesting aspects of computability.

If F : \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } \to \mathbb {N} is continuous in this sense, the function F can be described completely by whether the information g(0) = m_0, \ldots , g(r-1) = m-1 is sufficient to determine the value of F(g), and if it is, what this value is. But this information that completely determines F is finite and itself be represented as a function f_F \in \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} }, defined as f( \langle m_0, \ldots , m_{r-1} \rangle ) \vcentcolon \equiv \begin {cases} m + 1 & \mathsf {if} \ g(0) = m_0 \wedge \cdots \wedge g(r-1) = m_{r-1} \rightarrow F(g) = m \ \\ 0 & \mathsf {if} \ g(0) = m_0 \wedge \cdots \wedge g(r-1) = m_{r-1} \ \mathsf {does \ not \ suffice \ to \ determine} \ F(g) \end {cases}

The idea of the partial application operation is to take such an f_F encoding a function F : \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } \to \mathbb {N} and to determine the value of F(g) using the continuity data encoded by f_F. This brings us to the definition of this application operation.

Let
\langle {-} \rangle denote some computable coding operation \mathsf {List}( \mathbb {N} ) \to \mathbb {N}, and
\mu denote the minimization operator.

Given two functions f, g : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N}, the application of f to g is defined as follows: f \ | \ g \quad \vcentcolon \equiv \quad f( \langle g(0), \ldots , g(r - 1) \rangle ) where r \vcentcolon \equiv \mu r. \ f( \langle g(0), \ldots , g(r - 1) \rangle ) > 0
Defined in Section 3.2.1 of Longley and Normann's book.
So this operation gives us a function {-} \ | \ {-} : \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } \times \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } \rightharpoonup \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} }
Kleene's second model (often denoted \mathsf {K_2}) is the structure ( \mathbb {N} ^{ \mathbb {N} } , {-} \ | \ {-}).
Kleene's countable functionals extend this idea from types of degree 2 to types of arbitrary degree i.e. higher types.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Frame (type-theoretic)
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Defn. 2.4 from Patch MFPS

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
A ( \mathcal {U} , \mathcal {V} , \mathcal {W} )-frame L consists of a
a type |L| : \mathcal {U}
a partial order - \le - : |L| \to |L| \to \Omega _{ \mathcal {V} },
a top element \mathbf {1} : |L|,
an operation - \wedge - : |L| \to |L| \to |L| giving the greatest lower bound U \wedge V of any two U, V : |L|.
an operation \bigvee - : \mathsf {Fam} _{ \mathcal {W} }(|L|) \to |L| giving the least upper bound \bigvee _{i : I} U_i of any \mathcal {W}-family \left \{ U_i \right \} _{i : I}.
such that binary meets distribute over arbitrary joins, i.e. U \wedge \bigvee _{i : I} V_i = \bigvee _{i : I} U \wedge V_i for every U : |L| and \mathcal {W}-family \{ V_i \} _{i : I} in |L|.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This forest is currently a work in progress and has not yet reached version 1.0.
Everything here (including citations and attributions) should be treated as WIP.
Over the next couple of months, I will be revising and polishing the trees in this forest, that started as a small experiment with forest.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zoo of notions of (im)predicativity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: notes from a talk by Escardó, with some additions by Ayberk Tosun

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Russell's ramified type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all sets of a given type gives a set of the next type.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of Russell’s Reducibility Axiom
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: pp. 241 of Mathematical Logic based on the Theory of Types

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Axiom of Reducibility states that any truth function (i.e. propositional function) can be expressed by a formally equivalent predicative truth function.
This is where the term “predicative” originates from as it says propositional functions can be reduced to predicates.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of System F
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Martín H. Escardó's lab lunch talk

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over all types in the first universe gives a type in the first universe.
This form of impredicativity is also present in the Calculus of Constructions and the Calculus of Inductive Constructions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of topos logic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Aczel's CZF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Forming powersets is not allowed.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of MLTT

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Quantification over the types in one universe gives a type in the next universe.
This is similar to axt-005Z.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is the same as axt-0062 since HoTT/UF is a system extending a particular MLTT with univalence and so-called higher-inductive types.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Impredicativity in the sense of HoTT/UF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Voevodsky’s propositional resizing axiom is assumed. There are several forms of this axiom of varying strengths but they are all variations of the statement that propositional types quantifying over other types are small.
This seems to be somewhat similar to axt-0067.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Predicativity in the sense of Feferman

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any theory that has the strength of the Feferman-Schütte ordinal or above is deemed to be impredicative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formal Topology in Univalent Foundations
